Mike:

your responses surprise me (only a bit<g>) since you are the one
per=
son on this list who has designed, and actively promotes, a
hyper-media typ=
e which you describe as:  "...machine-readable and
designed to be consumed =
by automated 'agents'."[1]

[1] http://stateless.co/hal_specification.html
=

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mamund.com/=
foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 10:42, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@gmai=
l.com> wrote:
> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@yahoo=
.com> wrote:
>> <snip>
>> Comparison with WWW is not fair. =A0There is a si=
ngle shared semantic
>> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so fa=
r) are way better
>> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
>>=
 </snip>
>>
>> think about what you say here: that there is a "shared seman=
tic"
>> understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (and
>=
> solely) in the head of humans?
>>
>> after careful review, i claim you wi=
ll find that there *are*
>> real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switc=
hes" that exist in the
>> real world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and=
 (when appropriate)
>> activated by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the=
 visual cues that
>> are rendered by common Web browsers via the messages s=
ent by servers
>> in the most ubiquitous human-centered hypermedia format o=
f the day;
>> HTML.
>>
>> "Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In th=
e case of HTML that
>> property is "created" by humans when they observe th=
e visual
>> "landscape" rendered by =A0Web browsers.
>>
>> Does anyone here=
 want to assert that this "semantic meaning" can
>> _only_ emerge when huma=
ns are *directly* involved in the real-time
>> interpretation of messages t=
hat contain these (or similar) markers?
>
> Afaict, there's a spectrum of s=
ophistication here. I haven't seen a
> client implementation which demonstr=
ates automated capabilities which
> come 'close' to that of a human, we're =
basically talking about the
> web's version of a Turing Test.
>
> Most of t=
he evidence so far suggests this is the case, although I am
> not an AI exp=
ert.
>
>> Or
>> is it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at le=
ast some
>> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>> =
"affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>>
>> It is my assertion t=
hat the latter is the case. I also contend that
>> making the assumption th=
at this is possible is a key step in advancing
>> the art and theory of dis=
tributed hypermedia.
>>
>
> I think it's an interesting research topic but =
the complexity of
> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's inevi=
table that only
> a small portion of your client base will behave this way =
(unless you
> control them all, in which case your system is not very distr=
ibuted!).
> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your applica=
tion in
> a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining =
the
> effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
>=
 challenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
> of=
 inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.
>
> Cheers,=

> Mike
